title: PHPheaders_sent()Function

metadata.description: Learn about PHPheaders_sent()Function with clear explanations and practical examples.

content_sections.title: Details
content_sections.content:
Example
If no headers are sent, send one:
<?php
if (!headers_sent()) {
header("Location: https://www..com/");
exit;
}
?>
<html>
<body>
...
...
Definition and Usage
The headers_sent() function checks if/where headers have been sent.
Syntax
headers_sent(
file,line
)
Parameter Values
Parameter
Description
file
Optional. If the file and line parameters are set, headers_sent() will put the PHP source file name and line number where output started in the file and line variables
line
Optional. Specifies the line number where the output started
Technical Details
Return Value:
TRUE if HTTP headers has been sent, FALSE otherwise
PHP Version:
4.0+
PHP Changelog:
PHP 4.3: Added the optional
file
and
line
parameters
More Examples
Example
Using the optional file and line parameters:
<?php
// $file and $line are passed in for later use
// Do not assign them values beforehand
if (!headers_sent($file, $line))
{
header("Location: https://www..com/");
exit;
// Trigger an error here
}
else
{
echo "Headers sent in $file on line $line";
exit;
}
?>
<html>
<body>
...
...

★
+1

summary: This tutorial covers PHPheaders_sent()Function concepts and techniques. You'll learn how to use PHPheaders_sent()Function effectively, including key principles, common patterns, and practical examples. By the end of this tutorial, you'll have a solid understanding of PHPheaders_sent()Function and how to apply it in your projects.
